text: High expression of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells

<extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces two potent inhibitors of JAKs ( <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins ) <extra_id_0> that <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> not only act as mediators of negative feedback inhibition , but also play a major role in crosstalk inhibition by opposing other cytokine - signaling pathways [ 7 ] .

<extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has recently been shown to specifically inhibit <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation induced by <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but not by <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , thereby regulating the divergent action of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 8 , 9 ] .

On the contrary , <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is able to partially inhibit <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation and cellular responses , as well as <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation [ 32 ] .

To determine whether SOCSs were involved in the defective <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation of RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , the levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression in PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA patients and from healthy controls were compared by semiquantitative real-time PCR .

The RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells contained higher levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but lower levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcripts than did control <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( Fig . 6a ) .

Constitutive expression of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells was comparable with the expression in normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells stimulated by 10 ng / ml <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Fig . 6b ) , supporting its functional significance .

Defective <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation therefore appears to be due at least in part to an abundance of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .
